insights.summary: The NeuroReach VR system is a mixed-reality application under development for stroke rehabilitation, focusing on improving arm muscle activation through engaging, adaptive tasks.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system is a proof-of-concept mixed-reality application designed to assist stroke rehabilitation by enhancing selective muscle activation in the arms of survivors (c0001). It employs gamified elements and intuitive feedback mechanisms, including visual, auditory, and haptic cues, to boost user motivation and learning (c0001, c0002). The system incorporates tasks like ARAT-aligned pouring and MX Ink tracing, with adaptive difficulty and feedback that transitions from performance to results as the user progresses (c0001, c0003). While the evidence details the system's development and technical features, its direct clinical effectiveness and specific methods for measuring muscle activation improvement are still areas for further exploration (c0001).

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.

brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

insights.summary: Technical development of the NeuroReach VR system involves creating specific tasks and addressing challenges related to spatial anchors, tilt estimation, and feedback implementation.
insights.text: The development of the NeuroReach VR system includes building a Unity project with spatial anchors and passthrough capabilities, alongside specific tasks like a Passthrough Pouring task and an MX Ink Tracing task (c0004). Technical hurdles such as anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support are being actively addressed through solutions like anchor relocalization and data filtering (c0004). The system also features an adaptive controller designed to modify task parameters based on user performance, with implemented solutions to prevent issues like overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift (c0003). A projected dashboard is planned to display real-time performance metrics, though the evidence focuses on the details and implementation challenges of these specific metrics (c0002).

actions.title: Validate the direct impact of NeuroReach VR on selective muscle activation in stroke survivors.
actions.detail: While c0001 states the system aims to improve selective muscle activation, the current evidence (c0001, i0001) focuses on the system's design and technical development. A crucial next step is to design and conduct studies that directly measure and validate the improvement in selective muscle activation in stroke survivors using the NeuroReach VR system. This would involve defining specific metrics for 'selective muscle activation' and demonstrating their improvement through the system's use.

actions.title: Clarify the mechanism of adaptive difficulty based on muscle activation.
actions.detail: Challenge c0002 highlights a discrepancy between the claim of adaptive difficulty based on muscle activation and the evidence which details adaptation based on performance metrics and feedback fading (c0002). Further clarification is needed on how muscle activation data is captured, processed, and translated into adaptive difficulty adjustments within the system. This could involve detailing the specific sensors used and the algorithms that link muscle activation levels to changes in task parameters.

actions.title: Hypothesize the long-term clinical efficacy and user adherence of NeuroReach VR.
actions.detail: The current evidence (c0001, i0001) focuses on the proof-of-concept and technical development of NeuroReach VR. A forward-looking hypothesis is that the gamified environment, intuitive feedback, and adaptive nature of the system (c0002, c0003) will lead to sustained user engagement and improved long-term rehabilitation outcomes for stroke survivors. Future research should aim to test this hypothesis through longitudinal studies.

actions.title: Investigate the integration and effectiveness of the adaptive controller in a holistic rehabilitation context.
actions.detail: Challenge c0003 points out that the evidence focuses on technical solutions for individual components of the adaptive controller rather than its overall system-level function and impact. A next step is to investigate how the adaptive controller, as described in c0003, functions as a cohesive unit to dynamically adjust rehabilitation parameters based on user performance. This would involve evaluating its effectiveness in providing a personalized and progressive rehabilitation experience beyond individual component optimizations.

actions.title: Clarify the specific biofeedback mechanisms beyond general biofeedback for selective muscle activation.
actions.detail: Challenge c0001 raises the point that the evidence does not explicitly detail how selective muscle activation is measured or achieved beyond general biofeedback. A clarification is needed on the specific types of biofeedback (e.g., visual, auditory, haptic) that are directly linked to and designed to enhance selective muscle activation. Understanding these specific mechanisms will be crucial for assessing the system's targeted therapeutic approach.

challenges.claim_text: The NeuroReach VR system is a proof-of-concept mixed-reality application designed to aid stroke rehabilitation. It focuses on improving selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors. The system utilizes an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task to achieve its rehabilitation goals. Visual, auditory, and haptic feedback are integrated into the training tasks to enhance user engagement and learning. [1, 6, 2].
challenges.summary: The claim states the NeuroReach VR system is designed to aid stroke rehabilitation, but the evidence primarily focuses on its development and technical aspects rather than its effectiveness in rehabilitation.
challenges.detail: The claim asserts that the NeuroReach VR system is designed to aid stroke rehabilitation by improving selective muscle activation. However, the provided evidence snippets detail the system's development, including its technical components like ARAT-aligned pouring and MX Ink tracing tasks, integrated feedback mechanisms (visual, auditory, haptic), and adaptive controller functionalities. While E1 mentions 'potential for clinical application' and E2 outlines a 'Pilot study and analysis' phase, there is no direct evidence presented that demonstrates the system's actual efficacy or success in rehabilitating stroke survivors. The focus is on the 'how' of the system's creation and functionality, not the 'why' it is effective for rehabilitation.

Look for studies that compare the NeuroReach VR system's performance against traditional rehabilitation methods or other VR systems.
Investigate the results of the planned pilot study mentioned in E2 to understand its findings regarding rehabilitation efficacy.

challenges.claim_text: The system incorporates a gamified environment to increase user motivation during rehabilitation exercises. Intuitive feedback mechanisms are a key component, contributing to the system's potential for clinical use. A projected dashboard will display real-time performance metrics such as path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC. Adaptive difficulty and fading feedback will be adjusted based on the user's muscle activation, as observed through the dashboard. [2].
challenges.summary: The claim states the system uses adaptive difficulty based on muscle activation, but the evidence only mentions adaptation based on performance metrics and feedback fading.
challenges.detail: The claim (c0002) asserts that the system's adaptive difficulty and fading feedback are adjusted based on the user's muscle activation, as observed through a dashboard. However, the provided evidence snippets (E1, E2, E3) describe adaptive mechanisms related to performance metrics like 'path, tilt window, spills proxy' (E2), 'corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel' (E1), and 'on path, tilt window and spill proxy' (E3). Evidence E1 also mentions 'feedback fading from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results'. There is no explicit mention of muscle activation being the direct input for adjusting difficulty or feedback in the provided text. This suggests a potential overstatement or misinterpretation in the claim regarding the basis of adaptation.

challenges.claim_text: The NeuroReach VR system is a proof-of-concept mixed-reality application designed to aid stroke rehabilitation. It focuses on improving selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors. The system utilizes an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task to achieve its rehabilitation goals. Visual, auditory, and haptic feedback are integrated into the training tasks to enhance user engagement and learning. [1, 6, 2].
challenges.summary: The claim mentions improving selective muscle activation, but the evidence does not explicitly detail how this specific goal is measured or achieved beyond general biofeedback.
challenges.detail: The claim highlights that the NeuroReach VR system focuses on improving 'selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors.' While E1 mentions an 'OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION' with the goal of 'EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing,' this is presented as an optional extension and not a core, confirmed feature of the system as described in the claim. The evidence also mentions 'real time halos, ticks and error bars' and 'on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC' being updated, which are performance metrics for the tasks. However, it's not clear how these metrics directly translate to or are used to specifically measure and improve 'selective muscle activation' as stated in the claim. The connection between the feedback and task performance metrics and the specific goal of selective muscle activation remains an unanswered question.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.

Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,

challenges.claim_text: The system incorporates a gamified environment to increase user motivation during rehabilitation exercises. Intuitive feedback mechanisms are a key component, contributing to the system's potential for clinical use. A projected dashboard will display real-time performance metrics such as path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC. Adaptive difficulty and fading feedback will be adjusted based on the user's muscle activation, as observed through the dashboard. [2].
challenges.summary: The claim mentions a projected dashboard displaying real-time metrics, but the evidence details specific metrics and challenges related to their implementation.
challenges.detail: The claim (c0002) states that a projected dashboard will display real-time performance metrics such as path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC. While E2 confirms that 'path, time in tilt window, spill proxy' are computed, and E3 mentions 'on path, tilt window and spill proxy' as outcomes for the pouring task, the evidence does not explicitly list 'RMS error' or 'SPARC' as metrics. Furthermore, E3 highlights challenges like 'noisy tilt estimation' and 'stable spill detection', which are directly related to the accuracy and reliability of the metrics mentioned in the claim. The claim's assertion of these metrics being displayed in real-time via a dashboard is not fully substantiated by the provided snippets, which focus more on the development and challenges of specific task components.
